title-group.article-title: THE COMBUSTION OF FUELS IN THE INTERNAL-COMBUSTION ENGINE

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright, 1922, Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: The behavior of various fuels during combustion is merely one phase of the fuel problem. The author first reviews some of the salient points in the fuel problem proper. The chemistry of fuels, illustrated with diagrammatic structural formulas, is presented and the statement made that from the structure of a fuel its performance can be predicted very closely. An accurate indicator was a necessity in the fuelcombustion study; this was developed as described and illustrated. Fuel studies of most of the available fuels are given, including pressure-time and pressure-volume indicatorcards, followed by a review of the development of the theory of knock. Knock suppressors are discussed and statements made as to why certain compounds will stop knock when added to the fuel. The method of determining the necessary percentage of an anti-knock compound is indicated and several specific calculations are given and commented upon.
